claim_reports.claim_text: Only men who were citizens could vote in ancient Athens; women and slaves were excluded.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that only men who were citizens could vote in ancient Athens, explicitly excluding women and slaves. Multiple reliable sources confirm this exclusion.

supports.title: Ancient Greeks Voted to Kick Politicians Out of Athens if Enough ...
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that only adult, free male citizens were allowed to participate in Athenian democracy, explicitly excluding women, slaves, and metics (foreigners).
supports.snippet: ... excluded women, enslaved workers and foreign-born residents. Though ... Athens to vote a particular citizen to be ostracised from the polis.

supports.title: Democracy (Ancient Greece) - National Geographic Education
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that in ancient Athens, only citizens could participate in the democratic process, explicitly excluding women and slaves from voting rights.
supports.snippet: Democracy in ancient Greece served as one of the first forms of self-rule government in the ancient world. The system and ideas employed by ...

supports.title: If Athens Had Included Women: How a Broader Democracy Could ...
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that in ancient Athens, only adult, free male citizens were allowed to participate in the democratic process, explicitly excluding women and slaves from voting rights.
supports.snippet: The greatest silence of all was slavery. Enslaved people formed the backbone of Athens' economy, working in homes, mines, workshops, and ...

supports.title: Lesson 4: Direct Democracy in Ancient Athens
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that in ancient Athens, only citizens could participate in the voting process, explicitly excluding women and slaves from this democratic practice.
supports.snippet: Recommended Length: One class period. Key Ideas: Ancient Athenians practiced direct democracy. In direct democracy, every citizen votes on every issue, ...

claim_reports.claim_text: Democracy is a system where citizens have the power to choose their leaders.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that democracy is a system where citizens have the power to choose their leaders, as confirmed by multiple high-reliability sources that define democracy in terms of citizen participation in leadership selection.

supports.title: What is Democracy?
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that democracy allows citizens to choose their leaders and hold them accountable for their actions.
supports.snippet: Democracy is a means for the people to choose their leaders and to hold their leaders accountable for their policies and their conduct in office ...

supports.title: Democracy - Manual for Human Rights Education with Young people
supports.evidence_summary: The article defines democracy as a system where political power is vested in the people, emphasizing that in representative democracies, citizens elect their leaders through competitive elections, which aligns with the claim.
supports.snippet: There are so many different models of democratic government around the world that it is sometimes easier to understand the idea of democracy in terms of what it ...

supports.title: What Is Democracy, and Why Does Defending It Matter?
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence describes democracy as a system based on the will and consent of the governed, which implies that citizens have the power to choose their leaders.
supports.snippet: Democracy is a governing system based on the will and consent of the governed, institutions that are accountable to all citizens, adherence to the rule of law,

supports.title: Who Decides What Is Democratic? | Journal of Democracy
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that democracy involves citizens collectively deciding who governs them, which aligns with the claim that citizens have the power to choose their leaders.
supports.snippet: Democracy is a system in which citizens collectively decide by whom and, to some extent, how they will be governed.

supports.title: [PDF] Democracy in the United States - USCIS
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence clearly defines democracy as a system where political power is vested in the people, who elect their leaders through competitive elections, thus confirming the claim that citizens have the power to choose their leaders.
supports.snippet: Here, citizens vote for their government officials. These officials represent the citizens' ideas and concerns in government. Voting is one way to participate ...

claim_reports.claim_text: In a democratic system, citizens vote to elect their leaders.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence overwhelmingly supports the claim that in a democratic system, citizens vote to elect their leaders. Multiple high-reliability sources, including the Congresswoman Jan Schakowsky's statement and the AP News explainer, confirm that voting is a fundamental aspect of democracy, allowing citizens to choose their representatives directly or indirectly.

supports.title: Democracy and Voting Rights | Congresswoman Jan Schakowsky
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that in a democratic system, American citizens have the right to vote and choose their representatives, which is described as a fundamental building block of democracy.
supports.snippet: A fundamental building block of our democracy is the right of American citizens to vote and choose their representatives. Election Day is Tuesday, November 5th.

supports.title: EXPLAINER: How do other democratic nations select leaders?
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that in democratic systems, leaders are selected through voting, either directly by citizens or indirectly through parliamentary systems.
supports.snippet: In other democratic countries, heads of government are either directly elected by voters or by a parliamentary system in which the party winning the most seats ...

supports.title: Representative democracy | Definition, History, Discussion, & Facts
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that in a democratic system, citizens have the right to vote and choose their representatives, which is a fundamental aspect of representative democracy.
supports.snippet: A representative democracy is a political system in which citizens of a country or other political entity vote for representatives to handle ...

supports.title: U.S. stands out in how it picks a head of state - Pew Research Center
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that in a significant number of democracies, specifically 65 out of 125, the head of state is directly elected by voters, supporting the claim that citizens vote to elect their leaders.
supports.snippet: In more than half (65) of the world's 125 democracies, the head of state – nearly always called a president – is directly elected by voters.

supports.title: [PDF] Participating in a Democracy - USCIS
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that in a democratic system, citizens have the right to vote and choose their representatives, which is a fundamental aspect of democracy.
supports.snippet: By voting, citizens are participating in the democratic process. Citizens vote for leaders to represent them and their ideas, and the leaders support the ...

supports.title: The workings of democracy - Government.nl
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that in a democratic system, citizens participate in the electoral process by voting for representatives who they believe will advocate for their interests.
supports.snippet: Citizens elect their representatives, choosing people they feel will promote their interests. Representatives must therefore be aware of the social issues of ...

claim_reports.claim_text: In ancient Athens, citizens gathered in an assembly to discuss laws.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that in ancient Athens, citizens gathered in assemblies, specifically the Ekklesia, to discuss and vote on laws and other important issues, as confirmed by multiple high-reliability sources.

supports.title: CLCV 205 - Lecture 16 - Athenian Democracy (cont.)
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that in ancient Athens, citizens gathered in assemblies to discuss and vote on laws and other important issues, highlighting the participatory nature of Athenian democracy.
supports.snippet: Overview. In this lecture, Professor Kagan continues to discuss the constitution of Athens. In particular, he explores the judicial workings of Athens.

supports.title: Discussion Series: Athenian Law Lectures
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that in ancient Athens, citizens gathered in an assembly known as the Ekklesia to discuss laws and vote on various issues, allowing them to actively participate in governance.
supports.snippet: The Assembly (the “Ekklesia”) was the regular opportunity for all male citizens of Athens to speak their minds and exercise their votes regarding the government ...

supports.title: Ecclesia | Athenian Democracy, Direct Democracy, Citizen Assembly
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that Athenian citizens had the right to participate in assembly meetings, which were crucial for discussing laws and governance in ancient Athens.
supports.snippet: In 507 BCE, under the leadership of Cleisthenes, the citizens of Athens began to develop a system of popular rule that they called democracy, ...

supports.title: The Assembly of Athens Known as the Ecclesia - ThoughtCo
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that Athenian citizens participated in assemblies, specifically the Ecclesia, to discuss and influence political decisions, aligning with the claim about citizens gathering to discuss laws.
supports.snippet: The Ecclesia was a meeting place where Athenian citizens discussed and influenced political decisions. At 18, Athenian males joined their ...

claim_reports.claim_text: The French Revolution marked a significant turning point for democracy.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that the French Revolution marked a significant turning point for democracy, highlighting its influence on democratic ideals in the U.S. and the introduction of liberal democratic principles in France, as noted in high-reliability sources like the State Department and Britannica.

supports.title: The United States and the French Revolution, 1789–1799
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence discusses how the French Revolution inspired hopes for democratic reforms in the U.S. and influenced American political factions, indicating its significance as a turning point for democracy.
supports.snippet: The United States remained neutral, as both Federalists and Democratic-Republicans saw that war would lead to economic disaster and the possibility of invasion.

supports.title: UE: POL 110-HA: Democracy in Troubled Times: French Revolution
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence discusses how the French Revolution inspired democratic ideals and political changes in the United States, indicating its significance as a turning point for democracy, despite the ensuing political instability and radicalism that caused concern among some Americans.
supports.snippet: The French Revolution convulsed Europe in the name of equality, overturning the absolute monarchy of France, casting off the influence of the feudal aristocracy ...

supports.title: Influence of the French Revolution - Britannica
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that the French Revolution introduced fundamental principles of liberal democracy and significantly influenced modern political discourse in France, marking a turning point for democracy.
supports.snippet: It led to the rise of centralized and unified modern states, thus furthering modern concepts of nationalism (as in Italy and Germany, which ...

supports.title: French Revolution - Wikipedia
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that the French Revolution introduced fundamental principles of liberal democracy, which continue to influence modern French political discourse, thus supporting the claim that it marked a significant turning point for democracy.
supports.snippet: Many of the revolution's ideas are considered fundamental principles of liberal democracy, and its values remain central to modern French political discourse.

supports.title: How the French democratic revolution was won - Liberation School
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence discusses how the French Revolution was a pivotal moment for democracy, as it replaced the hierarchical feudal system with one based on the principles of liberty, fraternity, and equality, although it primarily established bourgeois democratic rights.
supports.snippet: The French Revolution secured the political rule of the capitalist class. It cleared the way for the capitalist economy to develop freely, ...

claim_reports.claim_text: Civic education plays a crucial role in sustaining democracy.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that civic education plays a crucial role in sustaining democracy. Three high-reliability sources emphasize its importance in fostering political literacy, enhancing civic participation, and maintaining democratic values, particularly in the face of rising authoritarianism.

supports.title: A Cry for Help: Civic Education in Today's America
supports.evidence_summary: The article emphasizes the importance of civic education in fostering political literacy and sustaining democracy, particularly in the context of rising authoritarianism. It argues that a lack of effective civic education has contributed to political illiteracy, which can lead to support for authoritarian leaders, thus highlighting the crucial role civic education plays in maintaining democratic values.
supports.snippet: The Constitution contains an implied right to an education that adequately prepares students to become capable citizens and participate in democracy.

supports.title: Educating for Democracy: The Case for a New Civics
supports.evidence_summary: The article emphasizes the importance of civic education in preparing young people to engage in democracy, highlighting that formal education programs can enhance political knowledge, civic participation, and democratic values, which are crucial for sustaining democracy.
supports.snippet: This situation urgently calls for excellent civic education to foster informed and engaged citizens prepared to uphold democratic values and processes.

supports.title: The need for civic education in 21st-century schools | Brookings
supports.evidence_summary: The article emphasizes that civic education is essential for sustaining democracy, particularly in the context of rising authoritarianism. It argues that a lack of effective civic education has contributed to political illiteracy, which can lead to support for authoritarian leaders, thus highlighting the importance of civic education in maintaining democratic values and norms.
supports.snippet: Americans' participation in civic life is essential to sustaining our democratic form of government. Without it, a government of the people, by the people, and ...

claim_reports.claim_text: Democracy has evolved over centuries and continues to be refined.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: Multiple high-reliability sources consistently discuss the evolution of democracy from ancient forms to modern systems, emphasizing its ongoing refinement and adaptation to societal needs. The NYU article and Our World in Data both highlight the transformation of democratic ideals over centuries, reinforcing the claim.

supports.title: Democracy's Shapeshifting Past—and Its Uncertain Future - NYU
supports.evidence_summary: The article discusses the evolution of democracy from ancient forms to modern representative systems, highlighting how democratic ideals have transformed political organization over centuries. It emphasizes that democracy has been refined and adapted through historical developments, indicating an ongoing evolution.
supports.snippet: David Stasavage, author of the newly released The Decline and Rise of Democracy, discusses democracy's past--and future.

supports.title: Democracy - Our World in Data
supports.evidence_summary: The article discusses the evolution of democracy over time, highlighting how it has changed from early forms of governance to modern democracies, which have expanded political participation and adapted to societal needs. It emphasizes that democracy continues to be refined as societies grapple with issues of trust and participation.
supports.snippet: The world has become much more democratic over the last two centuries · Two centuries ago, everyone lacked democratic rights. · Many democracies are less than a ...

supports.title: Understanding democratic decline in the United States | Brookings
supports.evidence_summary: The article discusses the evolution of democracy, highlighting how it has changed from early forms of governance to modern democracy, which emphasizes elections and broader suffrage. It suggests that democracy continues to be refined as societies grapple with issues of trust and participation.
supports.snippet: The United States is experiencing two major forms of democratic erosion in its governing institutions: election manipulation and executive overreach.

supports.title: Re-imagining Democracy 1750–1860 - Faculty of History
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence discusses the evolution of democracy from ancient forms to modern representative systems, highlighting how democratic ideals have transformed political organization over centuries.
supports.snippet: In the mid-eighteenth century, most people who talked about democracy thought that it was a primitive form of government, unsuited to the modern world.

claim_reports.claim_text: The word democracy comes from ancient Greek meaning citizens power.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that the word 'democracy' comes from the ancient Greek term 'dēmokratia', which is derived from 'dēmos' meaning 'people' and 'kratos' meaning 'power'. This is confirmed by multiple reliable sources, including a high-reliability article from The Conversation.

supports.title: The ancient Greeks invented democracy – and warned us how it ...
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that the word 'democracy' originates from the ancient Greek term 'demokratia', which is derived from 'dēmos' meaning 'people' and 'kratos' meaning 'power', thus supporting the claim that it means 'citizens power'.
supports.snippet: The term comes from the ancient Greek word demokratia. This is a combination of the words dēmos (meaning “people”) and kratos (meaning “power” ...

supports.title: Democracy (Ancient Greece) - National Geographic Education
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence explains that the word 'democracy' originates from the Greek 'dēmokratia', which combines 'dēmos' meaning 'common people' and 'kratos' meaning 'rule', thus supporting the claim that it means 'citizens power'.
supports.snippet: The ancient Greeks were the first to create a democracy. The word “democracy” comes from two Greek words that mean people (demos) and rule (kratos).

supports.title: Democracy - Wikipedia
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence explains that the word 'democracy' originates from the Greek term 'dēmokratia', which translates to 'popular government' or 'rule of the people', thus supporting the claim that it means citizens' power.
supports.snippet: The term appeared in the 5th century BC in Greek city-states, notably Classical Athens, to mean "rule of the people", in contrast to aristocracy (ἀριστοκρατία, ...

claim_reports.claim_text: The idea of universal suffrage emerged during the French Revolution.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence presents a mixed view on the claim that universal suffrage emerged during the French Revolution. The Britannica article indicates that the French Revolution contributed to the evolution of voting rights towards universal white manhood suffrage, but does not explicitly state that universal suffrage originated from it. Other sources provide unclear or conflicting information regarding the timeline and definition of universal suffrage in France.

mixed.title: Suffrage | Definition, History, & Facts - Britannica
mixed.evidence_summary: The article discusses the evolution of voting rights, particularly the transition from property qualifications to universal white manhood suffrage, which reflects the broader democratic ideals that emerged during the French Revolution, although it does not explicitly state that universal suffrage originated from the French Revolution itself.
mixed.snippet: Suffrage, in representative government, is the right to vote in electing public officials and adopting or rejecting proposed legislation.

claim_reports.claim_text: Today, democracy is based on the principle that everyone has equal rights and duties.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The claim is supported by the United Nations, which emphasizes that democracy is based on principles of equality and equal rights and duties for all individuals. However, other sources present unclear perspectives on the relationship between democracy and equal rights, highlighting the complexity of the issue.

supports.title: Democracy - the United Nations
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence supports the claim by emphasizing that democracy is based on principles of equality, human rights, and participation, where all individuals have equal rights and duties in the democratic process.
supports.snippet: The values of freedom, respect for human rights and the principle of holding periodic and genuine elections by universal suffrage are essential elements of ...

unclear.evidence_summary: Justice: Having a political order that protects the rights of all equally and treats everyone equally under the law.
unclear.snippet: Justice: Having a political order that protects the rights of all equally and treats everyone equally under the law.

transcript_data.text: what is democracy have you ever wondered how the people in a country get to decide who their leaders are and what rules they should follow this is all about democracy democracy is a system where the citizens of a country have the power to choose their leaders and influence the decisions made by the government the word democracy comes from ancient Greek meaning citizens power let's go back in time to see where this idea started in ient Athens citizens would Gather in an assembly to discuss and decide on laws and other important matters however it wasn't perfect only men who were citizens could vote while women and slaves were excluded fast forward to the 18th century the French Revolution marked a significant Turning Point French citizens overthrew the absolute monarchy and for the first time the idea of universal suffrage emerged this meant that any citizen regardless of wealth could vote however women still couldn't vote at this time over time Democratic ideas spread to many other countries today democracy is based on the principle that everyone has equal rights and duties it's about respecting each other and ensuring that everyone has a say in how the country is run in a democratic system citizens vote to elect their leaders and participate in the decision- making process this is done through elections where people choose their representatives the government is accountable to the people and the rule of law ensures that everyone is treated fairly civic education plays a crucial role in sustaining democracy it teaches citizens about their rights responsibilities and how to participate in the Democratic process this education helps people understand the complexities of political life and how to make informed decisions in summary democracy is about giving power to the people ensuring everyone's voice is heard and maintaining a fair and just Society it's a system that has evolved over centuries and continues to be refined to ensure equality and justice for all
